results.title: Rhino christmas
results.creator_credit: John Armstrong, Fiona Cochrane, Armstrong and Cochrane Productions
results.brief_description: It’s a hot and boringly predictable Christmas Day in the suburbs and Mott wishes it would snow. She’s sick of presents that are educational and of going to the beach with her new-age parents who meditate all day. But then weird things happen in this off beat fantasy.

results.title: Return from Witch Mountain
results.creator_credit: John Hough, Jerome Courtland, Ron Miller and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Sequel to “Escape to Witch Mountain” this family film is full of adventure and fantasy as Tia (Kim Richards) and her brother Tony (Ike Eisenmann), both who have supernatural powers, arrive on Planet Earth for a holiday. Dr Gannon (Christopher Lee) and his offsider Letha (Bette Davis) are trying to develop a mind-control device and when the evil Dr Gannon learns of Tony’s special powers, he kidnaps him, leaving it to Tia with her telepathic powers, and a motley gang of youngsters, to rescue Tony.

results.title: Rhine boatmen
results.brief_description: An account of the lives of the 40,000 men and women who live on the boats that trade up and down the Rhine, with some description of the river and its history.

results.title: Rethinking rape (Captioned)
results.brief_description: This is an in depth look at rape, particularly rape perpetrated by people known to the victim. In order to understand the high frequency of rape and its social causes, we must examine our cultural attitudes towards women, male/female relationships and rape itself. Six people of varying backgrounds, including a Rape Crisis Centre director, and a social psychologist, share their perspective’s on this topic.

results.title: Rewind, tape 2 eps. 14-26
results.creator_credit: Margaret Murphy, Film Australia, National Film and Sound Archive of Australia and SBS Independent
results.brief_description: A series of entertaining 5-minute history bytes narrated by Jack Thompson. Using newsreels, documentaries, home movies, television and cinema advertisements, each segment presents a snapshot of the evolution of everyday Australian life, attitudes and habits through the twentieth century. The segments are grouped around the six themes of “Rituals”, “Leisure”, ‘Rights and responsibilities”, “Environment”, “Building a society” and “Changing ways”. Tape Two contains episodes 14-26. They are entitled: “Fighting nature”, “Law of this land”, “Horse power”, “Your attention is requested”, “Sea around us”, “Dress sense”, “Great prospects”, “Making Australia home”, “Frozen images”, “A Fair Go”, “To be or not to be”, “Suburban dreams” and “A call to arms”.

results.title: Reternity: design of the 20th century
results.creator_credit: Futurniture, Torbjorn Lenskog, Annika Eriksson and Johanna Ekstrom
results.brief_description: In the winter of 1996-97, four Swedish and two British artists took part in an exhibition centred on Torbjorn Lenskog’s extensive collection of 20th century design objects at the Swedish National Art Museum. Their works engaged with the social life of these objects as design icons, addressing everything from the mentality of collecting, through the ideologies that informed modernism to the cultural malleability of industrial products. For this CD-ROM box set these artist were invited once again to make work in relation to the collection, this time specifically for the digital medium. The goal, as for the exhibition, was to stage a kind of confrontation between different ways of looking at history and its products. In addition to their works, which encompass a wide range of media, the CDs contain a large number of advertising images and photographs of the products in use, as well as excerpts from over 60 post-war documentaries that shed light on the industrial and social context that informed the design and reception of the objects. Quicktime objects and panoramas provide a close up of the items in collection.

results.title: Lewis Carroll country
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Last governor”.
The Sino-British talks collapse. In Hong Kong, support for Patten and his democratic reforms is undiminished despite an onslaught from the dissenters. With the help of Baroness Thatcher and other key players, this episode explores Patten’s inheritance; the 1984 Joint Declaration, under which Britain and China agreed terms for the handover of Hong Kong. Patten introduces his Reform Bill to the Legislative Council, the vote is make or break for him.

group_siblings.title: A Democratic time-bomb
group_siblings.creator_credit: Francis Gerard, BBC, Dimbleby Partners and Totem Productions

results.title: A Democratic time-bomb
results.creator_credit: Francis Gerard, BBC, Dimbleby Partners and Totem Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Last governor”.
Written and presented by Jonathan Dimbleby, episode one begins in 1992 as Conservative MP Chris Patten leaves for Hong Kong. He was the first politician and non diplomat to be elected governor, and he was the last governor of Hong Kong before the country was handed back to China. This episode looks at the business and democratic culture of Hong Kong, the influence of colonisation on culture, the role of the media in Patten’s term, an historical overview of Asia-British relations, and the migration of Chinese peoples to Hong Kong and their present status in Hong Kong society. The episode concludes with Patten having met with Chinese delegates to discuss the terms and conditions of democratic reform.
